item.title: Ukraine Confirms Another Small Gain in the South
item.description: Ukraine said that it had recaptured a total of eight settlements over two weeks of “offensive actions.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Blinken Meets Xi as China and the U.S. Try to Ease Tensions
item.description: U.S. diplomats visited Beijing to try to ensure that competition “does not veer into conflict.” The talks pave the way for a possible Biden-Xi meeting.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Leah Millis
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken meeting China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Faces New Indignity as He Awaits Vote in U.K. Parliament
item.description: The former prime minister may lose his pass to Parliament, another stinging blow from the fallout of lockdown-breaking parties during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving 10 Downing Street in central London in March 2021. He resigned in July 2022.

item.title: In Rush to Arm Ukraine, Weapons Are Bought but Not Delivered, or Too Broken to Use
item.description: Some of the weapons sent to Ukraine by other countries have been unusable, and hundreds of millions of dollars in contracts paid up front have yet to be fulfilled.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier preparing to fire an American-made M109 self-propelled howitzer toward Russian troops stationed in the city of Bakhmut in April.

item.title: In Argentina, Inflation Passes 100% (and the Restaurants Are Packed)
item.description: Argentina’s financial crisis has a surprising side effect: a flourishing dining scene in Buenos Aires, as residents rush to spend pesos before they lose more value.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba and Sarah Pabst
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Street-food patrons in an alley hot spot near Chinatown on a chilly May evening in the Belgrano neighborhood of Buenos Aires.

item.title: Ahead of Expo 2030 Bid, Rome Dreams of Reinvigoration
item.description: After years of decline, the city hopes to use a bid for the next world’s fair to re-envision itself as a place that works.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rome’s bid to host Expo 2030 would be centered on Francisco Calatrava’s Sail complex, intended to host aquatics championships but abandoned in 2007.

item.title: At Least 5 Palestinians Killed in Clashes After Israeli Raid in West Bank
item.description: A 15-year-old boy was among the dead and dozens more were wounded, Palestinian officials said. Seven Israeli security officers were hurt and a helicopter was later deployed, the military reported.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Alaa Badarneh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An explosion during an Israeli Army raid in the West Bank city of Jenin on Monday.

item.title: Germany and China Try to Reset Relations for a Changed World
item.description: This week the two countries will restart government consultations after a pandemic hiatus, but amid the war in Ukraine and rising U.S., Chinese tensions, common ground may be elusive.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Nicole Hong
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz at a news conference to introduce the new German security strategy in Berlin last week.

item.title: Once Scorned, Far Right Secures Foothold in Spanish Cities
item.description: Local alliances between the center-right Popular Party and the far-right Vox may foreshadow a broader coalition agreement at the national level.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Isabel Infantes/Reuters
item.media:description: The leader of the conservative Popular Party, Alberto Nunez Feijóo, at a rally in Madrid on Sunday.

item.title: ​North Korea Criticizes Officials for Failed Satellite Launch​
item.description: Top political leaders said the botched May 31 launch, which was meant to put a military spy satellite in orbit, had been “irresponsibly” planned.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, with other officials at a Workers’ Party meeting in Pyongyang, according to state media, which released this photograph on Monday.

item.title: Uganda Reels From Deadly Terror Attack
item.description: It was one of the worst terrorist acts to hit the nation in decades, as militants burned down dormitories with students still inside and hacked others to death.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Luke Dray/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Relatives mourning on Sunday outside a mortuary in Mpondwe, Uganda, where bodies of victims of a school attack were taken.

item.title: Egypt Is Upset by a Dutch Exhibit About Afrocentrism
item.description: A new exhibit in the Netherlands explores how Black musicians have drawn inspiration and pride from the idea that ancient Egypt was an African culture. Egyptians say it distorts their history and identity.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors viewing the “Egypt in Hip-Hop, Jazz, Soul & Funk” exhibition at the National Museum of Antiquities in Leiden, the Netherlands.

item.title: Indonesian Official Accused of Enslaving People
item.description: Families in Indonesia thought they were sending their sons to a rehab facility run by a powerful local official. Those who stayed there say it was a brutal human slavery operation.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Part of Terbit Rencana Perangin-angin’s estate, as seen from a cage where drug addicts were held, in Raja Tengah, Indonesia.

item.title: Uruguay Will Turn a Bronze Nazi Eagle Into a Dove
item.description: The artifact, once part of a German warship, was recovered by a private venture off Uruguay’s coast in 2006. It’s been the subject of a legal battle for years.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Richard Drew/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pablo Atchugarry, the Uruguayan sculptor, has been commissioned to transform a large bronze Nazi eagle into a dove.

item.title: U.S. Worries About Private Chinese Companies Aiding Russia, Blinken Says
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he urged Chinese officials “to be vigilant” as Washington continues to express concerns over possible military support to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Leah Millis
item.media:description: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: New Trial of Russia’s Jailed Opposition Leader Navalny Begins
item.description: If convicted, the charges could add decades to the prison terms that the jailed opposition leader is already serving.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Sergei Ilnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Alexei Navalny at a rally in Moscow in 2019. Mr. Navalny could receive another 30 years in prison if convicted in the new case.

item.title: The Racial Wage Gap Is Shrinking
item.description: Though still enormous, the gap has shrunk over the past five years.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tallulah Fontaine

item.title: Should Medicine Still Bother With Eponyms?
item.description: The names of Nazi-era doctors are still found on diseases and body parts. By expunging them, will doctors forget lessons of the past?
item.dc:creator: Rachel E. Gross
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Bri Hermanson

item.title: Russia Sought to Assassinate an Informant in the U.S.
item.description: A failed plot to assassinate a C.I.A. spy in 2020 in part led to expulsions of the agency’s chief in Moscow and his Russian counterpart in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Goldman and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Spies: The Epic Intelligence War Between East and West (Book)
item.media:credit: Gavriil Grigorov/Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: The clandestine operation represented a brazen expansion of President Vladimir V. Putin’s campaign of targeted assassinations.

item.title: Ukraine retakes some villages but its forces face minefields and more airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Shifts in global economic policy.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Blinken in Beijing
item.description: Also, Times graphics show how Russia likely blew up Ukraine’s dam.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Leah Millis
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken, left, with China’s foreign minister, Qin Gang, in Beijing on yesterday.

item.title: Northern India Endures Heat Wave, and a Wave of Deaths
item.description: Some doctors believe the high number of fatalities is tied to the temperatures. But the authorities are still trying to determine how many people died and what exactly killed them.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway/Getty Images
item.media:description: A resident painting her roof with reflective paint to keep her home cool in Jodhpur, India.

item.title: Israel Eases West Bank Settlement Rules, Clearing Way for New Homes
item.description: The change could accelerate the construction of thousands of new houses in the occupied territory and puts a far-right minister in charge of giving approvals.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jewish settlement of Tekoa in the West Bank. Most countries consider Jewish settlements in the occupied territories that Israel captured from Jordan in the Arab-Israeli War of 1967 to be in violation of international law.

item.title: Pope Francis Thanks Well-Wishers for Support During Hospital Stay
item.description: The pontiff, giving a public address for the first time since undergoing abdominal surgery, expressed gratitude for the “affection, care and friendship” he had received.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Tiziana Fabi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Francis speaking from the Apostolic Palace overlooking St. Peter’s Square in the Vatican on Sunday.

item.title: The Tyranny of Relentless Positivity
item.description: Samantha Irby is akin to our poet laureate of peevishness.
item.dc:creator: David Marchese
item.media:credit: E. Jason Wambsgans/Chicago Tribune via Getty Images
item.media:description: Samantha Irby

item.title: Ukraine Appears to Make a Small Gain in the South as Counteroffensive Continues
item.description: A Russian official and military bloggers said Sunday that Kyiv’s forces had retaken another village in their fight to recapture territory, a claim the Russian Defense Ministry denied.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the 28th Mechanized Brigade greeting each other near the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut.

item.title: Readers in Asia: Tell Us About Your Hometown’s Foods
item.description: We may include your response in the Asia Pacific Morning Briefing.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Why a New Coal Plant in Bangladesh Keeps Running Out of Coal
item.description: The problems are an early warning for countries, especially poorer ones, that are investing in new coal-burning plants even as solar and wind get cheaper.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Julfikar Ali Manik
item.media:credit: Fabeha Monir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fuel problems have halted operations at the plant for weeks at a time.

item.title: Blinken’s Visit to China: What to Know
item.description: There’s much to talk about, but it’s not clear if it will be constructive. Meetings in Beijing will offer clues as to whether the two nations can smooth over tensions.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Leah Millis
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken with Qin Gang, China’s foreign minister, in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Your Intentions for the Summer
item.description: Take some seasonal inspiration from what readers of The Morning are planning.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Deadnaming Children Would Be Allowed Under School Policy
item.description: The leader of New Brunswick, Canada, is pushing his province to roll back a rule that required teachers to use a child’s preferred name and pronouns.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gail Costello is part of a teachers’ group that pushed for gender identity-related school polices

item.title: As Floodwaters Recede, Ukrainian Authorities Brace for Possible Disease Outbreaks
item.description: Concerns about waterborne illnesses pose another challenge for Ukrainian officials as they report slow progress in the early stages of a counteroffensive aimed at taking back Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers in a flooded area in Kherson, Ukraine, this month after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam. Polluted waters are raising concerns about outbreaks of infectious diseases.

item.title: Canadian Wildfires, Bigger Than Ever, Test Foreign Firefighters
item.description: The first foreign firefighters to reach Quebec amid Canada’s worst wildfire season on record said that some of the blazes were 100 times bigger than any they had ever seen.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times

item.title: Taliban Rely on WhatsApp, but Keep Getting Kicked Off
item.description: The Taliban administration is stuck in a cat-and-mouse game with WhatsApp, which is off-limits to the nascent government because of U.S. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Safiullah Padshah
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Habib Rahman Inqayad, a Talib, in Kabul, Afghanistan, in April. Over the past two years, the Taliban’s reliance on WhatsApp has become far-reaching as smartphone use has proliferated.

item.title: Russia Shifts Battle Tactics After Mistakes
item.description: Moscow’s forces remain uneven. But while bracing for a counteroffensive, they have improved discipline, coordination and air support, foreshadowing a changing war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Arkady Budnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Russian conscripts training in October near Rostov-on-Don, Russia.

item.title: As U.S. and Chinese Officials Meet, Businesses Temper Their Hopes
item.description: Chief executives in the U.S. have long pushed for closer ties between the two countries. Now they just hope a rocky situation won’t get worse.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and David McCabe
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken is due to arrive in China on Sunday for meetings. U.S. business leaders have been pushing the Biden administration to restore some stability in the countries’ relationship.

item.title: Attack on Uganda School Kills Dozens
item.description: The authorities attribute the attack, one of the deadliest in years, to the Allied Democratic Forces, an extremist group based in neighboring Congo.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A boy is comforted on Saturday at the scene of an attack at the Mpondwe Lhubiriha Secondary School in Uganda.

item.title: Brazil Storm Leaves at Least 11 Dead, Others Missing
item.description: The governor of Rio Grande do Sul said it was a priority “to find the missing and save people who may still be stranded by the floods.”
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: via Governo do Rio Grande do Sul
item.media:description: Firefighters rescued patients from a flooded health care center in Sapiranga, a city in southern Brazil, an area hit by heavy rains on Friday.

item.title: African Leaders Visit Ukraine to Talk Peace With Russia
item.description: After meeting with the Africans, including some who have close ties to Moscow, President Volodymyr Zelensky suggested that their peace plans were unrealistic.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: African officials on a peace mission saw an exhibition of destroyed Russian military equipment in Kyiv on Friday.

item.title: Putin Asserts Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Has ‘No Chance’ at Economic Forum
item.description: By claiming to be in control at a pivotal moment, critics say, he can no longer pass any military failures off on others.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Pavel Bednyakov/RIA Novosti, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told members of the business elite on Friday at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum that Ukraine’s Western backers would tire of the conflict.

item.title: Republicans Attack Blinken for China Trip, Threatening Subpoena
item.description: Republicans rebuked the secretary of state for visiting China for diplomatic talks as they advocate a hard-line, military-first approach to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will visit China over the weekend.

item.title: ‘It Could Have Been So Much Worse’: Mountain Collapse Narrowly Misses Swiss Village
item.description: Fifty million cubic feet of rock came to rest just shy of Brienz and its schoolhouse.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Michael Buholzer/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A view of Brienz, Switzerland, after a massive landslide narrowly spared the village on Friday.

item.title: Nuclear Disaster Averted After Ukraine Dam Break. But What Threats Remain?
item.description: The destruction of a dam endangered the main source of water used for the critical task of cooling reactors and spent fuel rods at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Receding water levels are seen this month along the Dnipro River in Ukraine’s southeast, with the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, which is occupied by Russian forces, in the background.

item.title: Finland Shifts Right With Coalition Including an Anti-Immigration Party
item.description: When the party of the country’s political rock star, former Prime Minister Sanna Marin, lost in April, a center-right party’s power rose.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Johanna Lemola
item.media:credit: Alessandro Rampazzo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Petteri Orpo, leader of the conservative National Coalition Party, speaking in Helsinki in April. He is expected to become prime minister.

item.title: Victims in the Manitoba Crash Were 10 Minutes From Their Destination
item.description: A road trip to a casino turned deadly yesterday for 15 people aboard a bus in Manitoba, Canada, that collided with a semitrailer truck.
item.dc:creator: Kim Wheeler and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Nirmesh Vadera/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene of the crash Thursday near Carberry, west of Winnipeg, which killed 15 people, many of them elderly.

item.title: Greece Migrant Boat Tragedy Leaves Many Questions for Europe
item.description: Greek authorities blamed smugglers for a disaster that may have been one of the worst of its kind. Critics say tougher policies are increasing the risks.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Survivors of the wreck of the Adriana at a warehouse in the port of Kalamata, Greece, on Thursday. The authorities have recovered 78 bodies, but hundreds more are likely to have died.

item.title: Reading Spy Fiction, and About Those Who Wrote It
item.description: Extracurricular reading this week turned out to be very spy-focused, with appearances by John le Carré and Robert Gottlieb.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Christian Charisius/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The British best-selling author John le Carré in Hamburg, Germany, in 2017.

item.title: As Ukraine pushes to recapture territory, Russia moves ahead with elections in occupied areas.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A view of the Russian-occupied port city of Mariupol in Ukraine’s Donetsk region in April.

item.title: Boris Johnson’s Next Gig: Daily Mail Columnist
item.description: Britain’s former prime minister, who quit as a lawmaker in the face of a possible suspension for misleading statements about pandemic gatherings, will write for The Daily Mail, a tabloid.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Peter Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson described the report recommending his suspension from Britain’s Parliament as “tripe.”

item.title: Putin rejects claims that Russia is isolated, projecting a rosy economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Alexei Kudenko/Photo host Agency RIA Novosti, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the RIA Novosti state news agency shows President Vladimir V. Putin addressing the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum on Friday.

item.title: American Woman Dies at Neuschwanstein Castle in Cliff-Top Attack
item.description: The woman, 21, was visiting the popular German site with a friend when they met a man who persuaded them to take a little-used trail and then assaulted them both, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Neuschwanstein Castle, in Germany. The other woman pushed down the cliff was hospitalized and in stable condition, the police said.

item.title: Germany’s security strategy aims to set priorities after Russia’s invasion, but offers few hard commitments.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Clemens Bilan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, center, along with members of his cabinet, introduced the country’s first comprehensive national security strategy on Wednesday.

item.title: Donald Trump Has a Polling Problem
item.description: Most Republicans still support Trump. But the polls still suggest the federal indictment is hurting him.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Donald Trump’s rallied outside Mar-a-Lago after Trump appeared in a New York courtroom in April.

item.title: Japan Changes Its Rape Laws to Require Consent
item.description: Japan’s previous laws on sexual assault did not mention permission and required that the crime include physical force. The new law also raises the age of consent to 16, from 13.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Kazuhiro Nogi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Japan’s Upper House of Parliament unanimously approved changes to the country’s sex crime laws on Friday.

item.title: As Blinken Heads to China, Suspicion Awaits Him
item.description: Even as Beijing prepares for a visit by the secretary of state, China’s leader has made clear his expectations of more hostile superpower competition.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will begin his visit to China on Sunday.

item.title: He Ran Sudan’s Iconic Acropole Hotel. Then He Had to Flee Khartoum.
item.description: Thanasis Pagoulatos led the family business, Khartoum’s oldest inn, through decades of tumult. Sudan’s latest breakdown proved too much.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thanasis Pagoulatos, whose family built up the historic Acropole Hotel in Khartoum, was forced to evacuate Sudan in April.

item.title: Tunisians Mourn a Hard-Fought Freedom Rapidly Slipping Away
item.description: When reflecting on their Arab Spring revolution, Tunisians often say that freedom of expression was the only concrete achievement. As the country slides back toward autocracy, that, too, is being quickly eroded.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hajer Tlili, in green, joined Mosaïque FM a year before Tunisia’s revolution. In its aftermath, she became a star political host.

item.title: Rescued From a Flooded Island Behind Russian Lines in Ukraine
item.description: To many, the destruction of a dam on the Dnipro River in Ukraine brought devastation. To some stranded in Russian-occupied territory, it brought freedom.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Maria Varenikova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kateryna Krupych, holding her daughter Maria, 4, after they were rescued.

item.title: Pope Francis Leaves Rome Hospital and Returns to Vatican After Surgery
item.description: Doctors have advised the 86-year-old pontiff to take it easy after an operation to deal with a hernia that caused painful intestinal blockages.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Guglielmo Mangiapane/Reuters
item.media:description: Pope Francis was discharged from the Policlinico A. Gemelli hospital in Rome on Friday.
